Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Investigating the Influence of Sea-surface Variability on Ice Sheet Mass Balance and Outlet Glacier Behavior using Records from Disko Bugt, West Greenland
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will further understanding of ocean-ice-atmosphere interaction around the Jakobshavn Isbrae and Disko Bay region of west Greenland, with a particular focus on the role of sea surface temperature and sea ice variability in modulating past outlet glacier behavior and ice sheet/cap mass balance (snowfall and melt) over the past two centuries. The PIs will reconstruct past environmental conditions in the Disko and Baffin Bay region based on new glaciochemical and stratigraphic records from three 100-m deep ice cores, several firn cores, and geophysical studies from three sites surrounding Disko Bay. Their field activities will commence in 2013 with the primary ice coring activity in 2014 and lab and computation work following to derive climate reconstructions from the cores. The results will complement recent glaciological studies of regional ice dynamic behavior, as well as recent paleoceanographic and glacial geologic reconstructions of conditions from this area and era. Das and Frey will each supervise a full-time PhD student, and Evans will supervise undergraduate research assistants and senior theses. A high school science teacher will also participate in the field work and interact with students at his school in Massachusetts as well as from the ice.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Washington part of this project aimed to select ice-coring sites on ice caps near the Western margin of the Greenland ice sheet and on the ice-sheet flank, and to develop time scales for cores extracted at these sites.  In preparation for the site-selection campaign in 2014, we used a combination of remote-sensing and climatological data to begin understanding the topography and glaciology of sites potentially accessible from Kangerlussuaq and Illulisuat, West Greenland.  We selected the flank sites based on general regional climatology, but needed more intensive analysis to find coastal sites.  Using high-resolution photogrammetry data provided by the Worldview satellites, we developed meter-scale digital elevation models (DEMs) of Disko Island and the Nuussuaq peninsula, and searched for substantial ice caps at high elevation that did not clearly have excessive crevassing.  We found two sites on Disko Island, and three on the Nuusuaq peninsula, and these became our field sites for the site-selection ground campaign.  In 2014, we traveled to two of the flank sites and to three of the coastal sites, and conducted ground-based radar surveys while the other members of our team made snow-pit and firn-core measurements.  The radar data showed that two of the coastal sites were potentially suitable for coring, and based on our radar data we selected an optimal location for each, where we were believed that the layering would not be badly disturbed by near-divide effects, and were the ice was thick enough to provide a long-term record.  Figure 1 shows surface topography and bed-elevation estimates for the site on the Nuussuaq peninsula that we eventually selected.

In 2015, the coring team drilled at three locations that we had selected, one on the ice-sheet flank, one on Disko island, and one on the Nuussuaq peninsula. The flank site and the Nuussuaq site each yielded high-quality cores, while drilling at the Disko site encountered a wet layer a few meters below the bottom of the 2014 firn core, which prevented further progress.  The University of Washington task was then to develop age-depth scales for the two successful cores.  Because the flank site did not penetrate a large fraction of the ice thickness, the development of the age-depth scale there was not complicated, and was calculated based on a small uniform vertical strain rate. The Nuussuaq core, however,  reached within a few meters of the bed, covering nearly 2500 years, so the layer thickness was significantly influenced both by vertical compression and by accumulation-rate variations.  We analyzed GPS ice-penetrating radar data both from our survey and from airborne surveys conducted by NASA’s Operation Ice Bridge to develop a detailed model of the bed topography beneath the Nuussuaq ice cap, which provided a precise estimate of the ice thickness at the coring site.  We used this information, combined with layer-age information from the core (provided by the Woods Hole group, in collaboration with Dr. Joe McConnell and the Desert Research Institute) in an inverse-modeling scheme that yielded an age-depth scale, and an uncertainty estimate that takes into account the accuracy of the age-depth picks, as well as the uncertainty in our estimate of the ice thickness.  We exchanged draft versions of this age-depth scale with the Woods Hole group, who used it to help locate more potential layer picks.  Figure 2 shows the final age-depth scale and the misfits for the picked layers, as well as the range of model ages that were less than 20% more complex than the best model.  Figure 3 shows the accumulation rates associated with the acceptible accumulation histories, and the model complexity as a function of the esimated ice thickness.  These plots show that there is a relatively narrow range of ice thicknesses that are consistent with the measured layer ages, and that these ages constrain the age-depth scale to within a few years, but that there is around a 20% range of accumulation-rate values that are consistent with these measurements.  We have a draft manuscript describing the inversion techniques and the field measurements that we expect to be finished in as Matt Osman completes his Ph.D work on the Nuussuaq and other cores.  

The data for this project have been submitted to ArcticData.io:

https://arcticdata.io/catalog/#view/arctic-data.14377.1
